content_1: .  According to the National Veterinary Laboratory, a total of 13 outbreaks of H5N1 have been confirmed in four provinces throughout Bhutan:  Chhukha, Thimphu, Mongar, and Dagana. Out of 8,599 birds, 412 died while the remaining 6,623 were culled to prevent further spread of the virus.  The source of these outbreaks remains unknown.  Various control measures being applied include quarantine, movement control, screening, and disinfection of contaminated areas.
content_2: .  Four confirmed cases of H5N1 were reported on poultry farms in the Kaski District of Pokhara on the 16th of January.  Officials have culled over 2,000 chickens, destroyed the feed, and are supervising the infected farms for the next couple of months to prevent further flu outbreaks.
content_3: Two outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza, H7N3, were reported on the 12th of January on two farms in the western Mexican state of Jalisco. Officials from Servicio Nacional de Sanidad, Inocuidad y Calidad Agroalimentaria (SENASICA) are reporting that out of 397,513 birds, 18,009 have died. To help prevent further outbreaks, birds at both farms will be culled. Further control measures include quarantine, movement control, and screening and zoning. The origin of these outbreaks remains unknown, and national surveillance will continue.
